docs.lead_paragraph: Empire Blue Cross Plans To Seek For-Profit Status Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York, one of the country's biggest nonprofit health care companies, said it would seek state approval to become a for-profit company that would no longer be the health insurer of last resort. To stay competitive, Empire is trying to convert its fee-for-service business to managed-care organizations, which can charge customers less but have little left over for social obligations. Empire said it would try to continue its traditional role by setting up a charitable foundation that would provide money to help more than 2.5 million New York residents who do not have health insurance. $(Page A1.$) Home Resales Slip Again Home resales fell modestly in August, the third straight monthly decline as the housing market showed signs of leveling off. The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing houses fell one-half of 1 percent to an annual rate of 4.13 million. $(D2.$) Plan for Japan's Finance Ministry Japan's governing coalition announced a program for reorganizing the powerful Finance Ministry. But the plan -- which would leave the ministry mostly intact while creating an independent financial inspection and supervisory commission -- will probably disappoint proponents of greater change. $(D4.$) Lehman Not So Likely a Target Investors and analysts cite a number of potential acquirers for Lehman Brothers, and a quarterly earnings increase will hardly dispel the talk. Still, the rumors may be overdone. Market Place. $(D10.$) Genetics Institute in 2 Deals The Genetics Institute said it had developed a library of several thousand genes and related proteins that could be scanned for potential treatments, and announced deals with Genentech and Chiron for low-cost access to the library in return for a share of profits from any resulting drugs. $(D4.$) Protein Design Labs' shares soared 61 percent. A drug it developed with F. Hoffman-LaRoche proved effective in preventing the rejection of transplanted kidneys. $(D4.$) Bid for Loewen Becoming Hostile Service Corporation International said it would pursue its acquisition of the Loewen Group, despite the Loewen board's rejection of a $3.1 billion buyout offer. $(D2.$) I.M.F. Sees Steady Global Growth The International Monetary Fund said it expected annual growth among industrial nations of around 2.5 percent until the year 2000. But it suggested that the United States raise interest rates to head off inflation. $(D5.$) What's That You Say? Have a Beer. Good advertising, the saying goes, sparks conversation. But can conversation spark good advertising? Heineken, the Dutch brewer, thinks so and its current campaign promotes its beer with a series of TV commercials that focus on snippets of conversations. Advertising. $(D9.$) S.E.C. Call for Metric Trades A member of the Securities and Exchange Commission said that American stock markets should convert to a decimal-based system of pricing within three years. $(D8.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, once one of the country's biggest insurers of last resort, plans to announce today that it will seek approval from New York State to become a for-profit company, bringing to a close its historic role as a safety net for the sickest people of the state. To make the transformation, Empire would establish a charitable foundation to provide money to help the more than 2.5 million New York residents who do not have health insurance.

headline.main: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS SEEKING TO BECOME FOR-PROFIT GROUP

docs.abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, once one of country's biggest insurers of last resort, will seek approval from New York State to become for-profit company, bringing to close its historic role as safety net for sickest people of state; to make transformation, Empire will establish charitable foundation to provide money to help over 2.5 million New York residents who do not have health insurance; planned conversion reflects fierce competition in health care market (M)

keywords.value: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS AND BLUE SHIELD

docs.lead_paragraph: In converting to a for-profit insurer, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York will also be distancing itself from the scandals that have plagued the company in the past. ''They have been moving in the direction of becoming like other commercial insurers and with this announcement Empire is now no different than any other insurance company,'' said Charles Brecher, a professor at New York University's Wagner School for Management.

headline.main: Empire Is Emerging from a Cloud

docs.abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York, which is converting to for-profit insurer, has been plagued by scandals in the past; in 1993, while company was enduring huge losses, investigation found that it was offering lucrative contracts to insiders and lavished perquisites on its executives; company's president, Albert E Cardone, and two other top executives, were forced to resign, and state created oversight panel to monitor Empire's operation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton has issued standing orders to his staff that overconfidence is the cardinal sin of front-running campaigns, and he tries hard to honor that dictum as he swoops around the country, striving to squeeze an extra hour of sunlight from the shortening days of fall. ''This is no time for complacency in the political campaign,'' the President told a Democratic Party fund-raising reception here this afternoon. ''Believe me, it is not over. In some ways, it may be just about to begin.''

headline.main: For All of His Admonitions, Clinton Shows Ebullient Side

docs.abstract: President Clinton has issued standing orders to his staff that overconfidence is cardinal sin of front-running campaigns, and he tries hard to honor that dictum as he swoops around country campaigning for re-election; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Women with maternity coverage would be assured hospital stays of at least 48 hours after childbirth, and mental illness would for the first time be put on a par with physical illness under legislation that cleared Congress tonight and that is expected to be signed by President Clinton. The two health measures were included in an $84.7 billion compromise spending bill for veterans and housing programs that passed the House, working under the deadline pressure of a fast-closing election-year session, by a vote of 388 to 25. The Senate passed the measure without debate earlier in the evening by voice vote.

headline.main: Congress Votes to Add Coverage For Childbirth and Mental Illness

docs.lead_paragraph: The best of all possible headlines for this column is ''Welfare Mom Meets Bottom-Line Guy.'' Unfortunately it's too big for the allotted headline space, so must be buried, wearing type too small for it, in that dull opening sentence. The temptation to commit pieties here is irresistible, but I confine the bromidic impulse to noting that mankind must ever make do with whatever the authorities choose to grant, be it ever so little.
docs.abstract: Russell Baker Op-Ed column contends that it is people with no lobby who ought to shudder every time somebody happily declares 'the era of big government is over'; maintains that this bloc is now being sized up as potential source of corporate profit; notes that Lockheed Martin, which makes billions selling weapons to Pentagon, recently named new senior vice president to put Lockheed into business of running welfare-reform programs for profit (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If the state cannot close a loophole, one legislator wants to make sure that people are at least warned about it. Assemblywoman Shirley K. Turner announced a bill yesterday to let expecting mothers know if they are not covered by the state law that requires insurers to pay for a 48-hour hospital stay after childbirth.

docs.lead_paragraph: A bitter three-and-a-half-year strike against the Bayou Steel Corporation ended today when the United Steelworkers of America agreed to a six-year contract that links pay increases to productivity and profit. The strike by the 210 steelworkers began on March 21, 1993, over an incentive pay plan, the use of subcontractors and company demands that workers pay a portion of their health insurance coverage.
docs.abstract: United Steelworkers of America, ending bitter three-and-a-half-year strike against Bayou Steel Corp, agrees to six-year contract that links pay raises to productivity and profit (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the campaign to oust the trustees of Adelphi University here, the dual roles of its board chairwoman, Ernesta G. Procope, have loomed large. The board's critics have accused her of a conflict of interest for serving simultaneously as Adelphi's chairwoman and as owner of the brokerage handling the university's insurance. Now, a group called the Committee to Save Adelphi has placed a price tag on the university's relationship with her company, the E. G. Bowman Company of Manhattan.

headline.main: Chairwoman of Adelphi's Board Is Accused of Using Her Double Role to Advantage

docs.abstract: Campaign to oust trustees of Adelphi University has focused on dual roles of its board chairwoman, Ernesta G Procope; board's critics have accused her of conflict of interest for serving simultaneously as Adelphi chairwoman and as owner of brokerage handling university's insurance; Adelphi has paid more than $7 million on insurance premiums arranged by her company, E G Bowman Co; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bob Dole held a chatty session with voters here in this northern Virginia suburb today, dragging out one of the Republicans' most popular props from the 1994 campaign to back up his ridicule of President Clinton as a hopeless liberal. Mr. Dole, speaking to about 500 people in the warehouse of a moving company, stood before a chart of the health-care plan that Mr. Clinton proposed three years ago and that eventually self-imploded. Republicans used the chart, as complex as a circuit board, to great effect in the 1994 campaign, which won them control of Congress. Mr. Dole drew laughter with it today when he said, ''The patient's finally there on the bottom.''

headline.main: Dole Uses Clinton Health Plan To Portray Him as a Liberal

docs.abstract: Bob Dole, campaigning in Springfield, Va, assails health-care plan that Pres Clinton proposed three years ago, and ridicules him as 'hopeless liberal'; photo (M)
